A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
Does the concept of a/an Ring Epimorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Free A-module is defined as an A-module M that has a basis, meaning it has a set of generators such that every element in M can be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of these generators with coefficients from the ring A. This definition focuses on the internal structure of the module M and its relationship with the ring A.

On the other hand, a Ring Epimorphism is defined as a surjective ring homomorphism from one ring R to another ring R'. This concept pertains to the relationship between two rings and the mapping between them, focusing on the properties of ring homomorphisms and their surjectivity.

The definition of a Free A-module does not inherently involve or require the concept of a Ring Epimorphism. The definition and understanding of a Free A-module can be fully established without reference to the concept of ring homomorphisms or their properties such as surjectivity. Therefore, the concept of a Ring Epimorphism is not necessary for the definition of a Free A-module to make sense.
